results.title: Caroline Cherie = Dear Caroline
results.creator_credit: Richard Pottier, Alain Poire and Paul Cadeac
results.brief_description:
Caroline de Bievres celebrates her 16th birthday on 14 July 1789. While the Parisians storm the Bastille, Caroline experiences love with Gaston de Sallanches. Sent to Paris by her parents, she discovers that Gaston is already married.

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire, Paul Cadeac ; director, Richard Pottier ; writer, Jean Anouilh ; photography, Maurice Barry ; music, Georges Auric ; art director, Jacques Krauss.
Cast: Martine Carol, Jacques Dacqmine, Pierre Cressoy, Jacques Clancy, Marie Dea, Daniele Seller, Paul Bernard, Alfred Adam, Raymond Souplex, Marthe Mercadier, Nadine Alari, Yvonne de Bray, Marie Dea, Olivier Hussenot.

results.title: J'ai Epouse Une Ombre = I Married a Dead Man
results.brief_description:
Helene is 8 months pregnant when she is abandoned by Frank, her companion. Lonely and desperate she boards the first train heading south. Aboard, she meets vineyard heir Bertrand Meyrand and his wife Patricia, also 8 months pregnant. During the night, the train is derailed. Bertrand and Patricia die during the accident. When Helene wakes up at the hospital, she realises that everyone mistakes her for Patricia, including Bertrand’s parents who offer her shelter at their wine growing property. Helene settles uncomfortably in her new family, until the day Frank comes back to blackmail her. The plot is based on a story by Cornell Woolrich and was filmed twice before as ‘No Man of Her Own’ in 1932 and 1949 in the U.S.A. In 1996 it was remade again as the romantic comedy ‘Mrs. Winterbourne’.

Credits: Producer, Alain Sarde ; director, Robin Davis ; writers, Robin Davis, Patrick Laurent ; photography, Bernard Zitzerman ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Nathalie Baye, Francis Huster, Richard Bohringer, Madeleine Robinson, Guy Trejean, Victoria Abril, Veronique Genest.

results.title: Les Maries de L'an II
results.brief_description:
A few year before the French Revolution, Nicolas kills one of his wife’s lover and must flee to America in order to avoid police prosecution. While in exile he becomes a successful spice merchant. Soon Nicolas is engaged to be married to a wealthy heiress. However, he must return to France, by now in the throes of the revolution, to obtain divorce from his wife and

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire ; director, Jean-Paul Rappeneau ; writers, Daniel Boulanger, Maurice Clavel, Claude Sautet, Jean-Paul Rappeneau ; photography, Claude Renoir ; music, Michel Legrand ; art direction, Willy Holt, Alexandre Trauner.
Cast: Jean-Paul Belmondo, Marlene Jobert, Michel Auclair, Laura Antonelli, Sami Frey, Denise Peron, Julien Guiomar, Charles Denner, Pierre Brasseur, Mario David.

results.title: Gribouille = Heart of Paris
results.creator_credit: Marc Allegret, Andre Daven and Roger Le Bon
results.brief_description:
Camille Moresteau is serving on a jury in a murder trial. Moresteau takes pity on Nathalie Rougin and invites her to move in with his family for the duration of the trial. Moresteau’s son Claude takes an immediate interest in Nathalie while suspecting his father to have views on the young woman. Sensing her presence is causing tension in the family, Nathalie prepares to leave but not before she has stolen some valuables from the Moresteaus. The film was remade as ‘The Lady in question’ in 1940 by Charles Vidor.

Credits: Producers, Andre Daven, Roger Le Bon ; director, Marc Allegret ; writer, Marcel Achard, H. G. Lustig ; photography, Armand Thirard, G. Benoit, Michel Kelber ; music, Georges Auric ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner.
Cast: Raimu, Michele Morgan, Pauline Carton, Gilbert Gil, Jacqueline Pacaud, Julien Carette, Jean Worms, Bernard Blier, Jacques Baumer, Andrex.

results.title: Le testament d'orphee ou ne me demandez pas pourquoi = The testament of orpheus or don't ask me why
results.brief_description:
Jean Cocteau as ‘The Poet’ wanders weightlessly through a dream landscape peopled by his friends, and the characters and images from his earlier films ‘Blood of a Poet’ (Le Sang du Poete) and ‘Orpheus’ (Orphee). The ageing poet knows he is dying (as indeed Cocteau was) and his greatest desire is to be reborn so that he can qualify for celestial immortality. This film is beautiful because it is the film of a man who knows he is going to die and still cannot take death seriously. Absurdity and grace are the two faces of the same medal that the poet throws into his night and falls back into our darkness”. Reference: Les Cahiers du Cinema, April 1960. The film was shot in the quarries of Les Baux de Provence, a highly mythical place, since Dante found inspiration for ‘The Divine Comedy’ in the same location.

Credits: Producer, Jean Thuillier ; director, Jean Cocteau ; writer, Jean Cocteau ; photography, Roland Pontoizeau ; music, Geoges Auric, Martial Solal ; stills photographer, Lucien Clergue ; costumes, Cristobal Balenciaga.
Cast: Jean Cocteau, Edouard Dhermitte, Henri Cremieux, Yul Brynner, Jean-Pierre Leaud, Francoise Christophe, Claudine Auger, Charles Aznavour, Francois Perier, Jean Marais, Pablo Picasso, Daniel Gelin.

results.title: Sous les Toits de Paris = Under the Roofs of Paris
results.brief_description:
A street singer falls for a pretty Romanian girl whom he protects from her lecherous lover, but he is accused of theft. ‘Sous les toits de Paris’ was one of the first French talkies and a remarkable experiment in sound, both technically and in its discourse on the possibilities of the new medium. Clair chose to use sound only when needed, preferring to tell the story through his visuals as much as through his dialogue. The result is a striking film, boasting beautiful photography and sets, as well as a moving story. The art direction by Lazare Meerson fixed an iconography of Paris - a sweet version of the darker ‘Poetic Realism’, full of street singers, irate concierges and neighbours, and pretty ‘midinettes’. This iconography is often re-used in the form of a nostalgic homage in recent efforts such as ‘Delicatessen’. Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The Companion to French cinema. London: BFI publishing, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Frank Clifford ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Georges Perinal ; music, A. Bernard ; art direction, Lazare Meerson.
Cast: Polla Illery, Albert Prejean, Gaston Modot, Jane Pierson, Edmond T. Greville, Raymond Aimos.

results.title: Une Femme Douce = a Gentle Creature
results.brief_description:
A young woman marries a pawnbroker but finds she cannot adapt her life to his. She toys with murdering him, but kills herself instead. With the introduction of colour in his films, beginning with ‘Une femme douce’, Bresson’s vision darkened, his growing pessimism disclosed in an increasingly voluptuous rendering of the world. (One might say sobriety invites intoxication.) The flatness of Bresson’s compositions and his emphasis on dedramatization places Bresson in the tradition of modernism, yet his universe often seems archaic.” Reference: James Quandt. The poetry of precision: the films of Robert Bresson. Cinematheque Ontario. Online. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/bresson.htm. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May-June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Philippe Dussart ; director, Robert Bresson ; writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Ghislain Cloquet ; music, W. A. Mozart, Henry Purcell, Jean Wiener ; art direction, Pierre Charbonnier.
Cast: Dominique Sanda, Guy Frangin, Jane Lobre, Claude Ollier, Dorothee Blank.

results.title: India Song
results.brief_description:
In the 1930s, Anne-Marie Stratter lives in Calcutta with her husband, the French Ambassador. During a reception at the Embassy, Anne-Marie dances with her lover, Michael Richardson, unaware of her husband’s glances. Anne-Marie is equally unaware of the passion in the vice-consul’s eyes. The vice-consul declares is passion to Anne-Marie. She rebuffs him. The vice-consul runs off and a heartrending cry tears the stillness of the night. Further viweing: In ‘Son nom de Venise dans Calcutta desert’(1976), Marguerite Duras re-uses the same soundtrack, this time accompanied with images of the Embassy, now deserted, where the action of ‘India Song’ took place. The closing sequence of ‘Son nom de Venise dans Calcutta desert’ is used as the opening sequence for ‘India Song’.

Credits: Producer, Stephane Tchalgadjieff ; director, Marguerite Duras ; writer, Marguerite Duras ; photography, Bruno Nuytten ; music, Ludwig van Beethoven, Carlos d’Alessio.
Cast: Delphine Seyrig, Michel Lonsdale, Claude Mann, Mathieu Carriere, Didier Flamand, Vernon Dobtcheff.

results.title: Ma Femme Est Formidable = My Wife Is Wonderful
results.brief_description:
Condemned without evidence as a ‘rake’ by his dimwitted wife Sylvia and his monstrous in-laws, Raymond Corbier is further bedeviled by the unwarranted advances of man-chasing Marguerite Rival.

Credits: Producer, Paul Cadeac ; director, Andre Hunebelle ; writer, Jean Halain ; photography, Paul Cotteret ; music, Jean Marion ; costumes, Pierre Balmain.
Cast: Sophie Desmarets, Fernand Gravey, Simone Valere, Alfred Adam, Jacques Dynam, Max Dalban, Pauline Carton, Suzanne Dehelly.
